meanings.definition: To wave or flutter in the wind
meanings.sent1: The colorful flags were willowing in the breeze.
meanings.sent2: The curtains were willowing gently as the window was open.
meanings.sent3: The kite was willowing in the sky, making the children laugh.
meanings.sent4: The leaves willowed gracefully as they fell from the tree.
meanings.sent5: The fields of wheat willowing in the wind created a mesmerizing sight.

meanings.definition: To beat or thrash with a willow branch
meanings.sent1: The farmer was willowing the wheat to separate the grains.
meanings.sent2: She was willowing the rug to remove the dust.
meanings.sent3: The naughty child was willowing his brother with a willow branch playfully.
meanings.sent4: The chef was willowing the dough to make it soft and fluffy.
meanings.sent5: The gardener was willowing the soil to prepare it for planting.

meanings.definition: To separate fibers by tossing them in the air
meanings.sent1: She was willowing the cotton to remove any impurities.
meanings.sent2: The traditional method of willowing silk involved tossing it in the air.
meanings.sent3: The old lady was willowing the wool, creating a cloud of fluff around her.
meanings.sent4: The artisan was willowing the fibers to make them softer and more pliable.
meanings.sent5: The process of willowing the flax was essential before spinning it into linen.
